prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA: I dont think its appropriate for someone in a relationship to hangout with a single person of the other gender.
I was having a conversation with some friends and I said that I wouldn't be ok with my wife meeting and hanging out with a guy thats single 1on1 (I still wouldnt like the fact if he was married as well) . I feel as though its inoppropite being in a relationship. Its not too serious of a matter because my wife agrees (being the roles be reversed), but my friends turned their noses up at me and I wanted an  judgement. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking if the author is in the wrong for saying they wouldn't be okay with their wife hanging out alone with a single guy. Let me break this down.

First, the author is in a relationship and expressed that they don't think it's appropriate for someone in a relationship to hang out one-on-one with a person of the opposite gender who's single. They also mention that their wife agrees if the roles were reversed. But their friends disapproved.

Hmm. The key here is whether the author's opinion is wrong. Well, it's their personal boundary, right? As long as both partners are on the same page, it's their choice. The author isn't imposing this on their wife; they just share their own feelings. Their friends' reaction is about differing views on relationships. Some people might think that being in a relationship doesn't mean you can't have friends of the opposite sex. But the author's stance is about their own comfort level. Since their wife agrees with the mutual exclusivity, there's no betrayal or harm. So the author isn't necessarily wrong for having those feelings. It's a personal preference within their relationship. Unless there's coercion, it's their decision. So the answer would be B, No.
